title: 107_s2844
content: The Act may be cited as the "Incentives to Educate American Children (I Teach) Act of 2002". Congress finds that there is a need for 2,000,000 new teachers in the next decade. The No Child Left Behind Act requires States to recruit qualified teachers by 2006, especially in rural and high-poverty schools. Rural education is crucial in 25 States, and high poverty schools often lack certified teachers in their fields. The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, established in 1987, sets high standards for accomplished teachers. High poverty schools face challenges in recruiting certified teachers, impacting their ability to meet education goals. The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, established in 1987, certifies teachers based on rigorous assessments. Recent data shows that certified teachers outperform their peers on key measures of teaching expertise. Recent data from the Accomplished Teaching Validation Study shows that National Board certified teachers outperform non-certified teachers on 11 out of 13 key measures of teaching expertise. Teacher salaries have remained stagnant over the past decade, with two-thirds of states not meeting the national average of $40,582. The purposes of the Act include encouraging teachers to work in rural or high-poverty schools through a refundable tax credit and providing an additional tax credit for National Board certification. The Act aims to incentivize teachers to work in rural or high-poverty schools through a refundable tax credit and provide an additional tax credit for National Board certification. The Act introduces a tax credit for individuals teaching in high poverty or rural schools and certified teachers. A tax credit is available for eligible teachers working in public schools in rural areas or high poverty areas. The credit amount is $1,000 for eligible teachers in these schools during the academic year. The tax credit amount for eligible teachers in public schools in rural or high poverty areas is $1,000 if the school meets specific criteria such as a high percentage of students receiving free or reduced-cost lunches or a School Locale Code of 7 or 8. The tax credit amount for eligible teachers in public schools in rural or high poverty areas is $1,000 if the school meets specific criteria such as a high percentage of students receiving free or reduced-cost lunches or a School Locale Code of 7 or 8. Eligible teachers certified by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards may receive $1,000, while those in rural areas or high poverty schools may receive $2,000. Eligible teachers are defined as kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teachers or instructors. The applicable amount for eligible teachers in public schools with high poverty is $2,000. An eligible teacher is defined as a kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teacher in a public elementary or secondary school on a full-time basis. Additional definitions include the terms 'elementary school' and 'secondary school' as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and an 'eligible academic year' is any academic year ending in a taxable year beginning after December 31, 2002. The terms 'elementary school' and 'secondary school' are defined by the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. An 'eligible academic year' is any academic year ending in a taxable year beginning after December 31, 2002. Amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Tax credit for individuals teaching in high poverty or rural areas and certified teachers. Effective Date: Amendments apply to academic years ending in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002.
